primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The movement from human depletion and regret (the wine running out) to divine abundance and restoration through the manifestation of Christ's glory.

tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus of Nazareth steps on the scene.
He has come to pour out his life for us.
Jesus... poured out more good wine than anyone had ever seen.
The wine so freely given represents Jesus’ gift of himself.
The future blessings of the heavenly kingdom had become present.
Jesus lives... according to God’s will. He must listen to another voice.

ontvanger.identificatie: The Hearer / Humanity / The Wedding Guests
tekstueel_bewijs: He sees us, he loves us, and he has come to pour out his life for us.

helper.identificatie: Mary (as model of faith) and the Holy Spirit
tekstueel_bewijs: She makes a space for him to act.
being built by the Holy Spirit into a fellowship of love.

tegenstander.identificatie: Sin, Regret, Death, and Ineffective Religious Ritual
tekstueel_bewijs: The wine has run out, and we are still in our sins.
It [religious ritual] is tasteless and colorless and joyless and it doesn’t take away sin.
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not just a lack of beverage, but the 'creeping chill' of death and the ontological failure of human effort to cure regret.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The response of the believer to the gift of grace: a life of service.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Saved Believer
secundair_narratief_programma.object: Service to others and God's suffering world
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The ethical life is explicitly framed as a result of being 'built by the Holy Spirit' after the primary act of Jesus.

actantieel_schema_visualisatie.zender_naar_ontvanger: God's Will → Abundant Life → The Hearer

voorbeelden_god_subject: Jesus of Nazareth steps on the scene.
He has come to pour out his life for us.
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We take refuge in all sorts of escapes.
We buy something and charge it.
We all agreed that it [regret] was part of life.

voorbeelden: Whatever he tells you, do it.
The ceaseless craving of the human heart.
Those who had eyes to see... recognized.
The Son of God is powerful to save.
The only One who is able to wipe away regret forever.

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon focuses on the 'Inability' of man (lack of wine/power) and the 'Ability' (Pouvoir) of Christ. It is a theology of Divine Capacity.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Starts at S2 (Regret), moves to ~S2 (Escapism), identifies the failure of ~S1 (Ritual), and resolves in S1 (Christ's Wine).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Christ transforms the failed ~S1 (water of ritual) into the S1 (wine of grace).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High; death and regret are presented as 'undoing' many.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon consistently places Jesus as the active Subject of salvation and the hearer as the desperate Receiver. Human effort (ritual or escapism) is shown to be incompetent.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: She is, as always, the model of the true believer.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus of Nazareth steps on the scene. He sees our predicament.
The whole world full of disease and violence and cruelty and death.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Mary is used as a model, but specifically a model of 'relinquishing' and 'making space,' which is a passive-receptive model rather than a performance-based one.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: Christ honors the faith he himself inspires in Mary.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief from the burden of self-salvation; comfort in the face of regret.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic grace: salvation is entirely God's work.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the 'empty glass' of human life to the 'bottomless glass' of Christ is seamless.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: The Son of God is powerful to save... the only One who is able to wipe away regret forever.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit builds the fellowship of love; it is an endowment of Pouvoir-faire.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Sin is linked to the 'creeping chill' of death and the failure of all human systems.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon is a textbook example of grace-oriented narrative structure. Jesus is the Subject, the 'Good Wine' is the Object, and the hearer is the Receiver.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain as is; this is appropriate for an Epiphany sermon.

tegenstander_intensivering.huidige_status: The opponent (Death/Regret) is already sufficiently heavy.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: Soteriology (Christ's gift) clearly precedes and enables Ethics (service).

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: The sermon masterfully avoids the trap of turning the Cana story into a lesson on 'doing what Jesus says' (moralism) and instead presents it as a sign of who Jesus is (grace).

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While a rhetorical analysis would focus on the poignant use of the 'personal ads,' semiotics shows these ads function as the 'Opponent' (the lack/deprivation) that necessitates the Subject's intervention.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis might focus on the meaning of 'Woman' or the 'six jars'; semiotics identifies the jars as a failed Helper (~S1) in the narrative economy.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas' model reveals that the sermon's power comes from the 'Subject-Switch'—the hearer realizes they cannot fill their own glass, and Jesus takes over the role of Subject.

volledige_subject_lijst: Jesus (steps, sees, hears, loves, comes, poured, gives, prepares)
We (take refuge, buy, drink, grab, read, climb)
The water (is used, doesn't work, represents)
appendices.notities: The sermon uses Rutledge's own criteria effectively, ensuring God remains the primary actor in the active voice.
